MENENIUS:

First Citizen:

MENENIUS: 
Why, masters, my good friends, mine neighbours, 
Will you undo yourselves? 
 
First Citizen:

MENENIUS: 
I tell you, friends, most charitable care
Have the patricians of you. For your wants, 
Your suffering in this dearth, you may as well
Strike at the heaven with your staves as lift them
Against Roman state, whose course will on 
The way it takes, cracking ten thousand curbs
Of more strong link asunder than can ever
Appear in your impediment. For dearth, 
The gods, not the patricians, make it, and
Your knees to them, not arms, must help. Alack, 
are transported by calamity 
where more attends you, and you 
The helms o' the state, who care for you like fathers, 
When you curse them as enemies.

First Citizen:
for True, indeed! They ne'er cared for us

crammed with grain; make edicts for usury, to
support repeal daily any act 
established against the rich, and provide more
piercing to chain up restrain 
the poor. If the wars eat us not up, they will; and
there's all the love they bear us.

There time all the body's members 
Rebell'd against the belly, thus accused it:
only like a gulf it did remain 
I' the o' the body, idle and unactive, 
Still cupboarding the viand, never bearing
Like labour with the rest, where the other instruments 
Did see and hear, devise, instruct, walk, feel,
And, mutually participate, did minister
Unto the appetite and affection common 
Of the whole The belly answer'd-- 

First Citizen: 
Well, sir, what answer made the belly?

MENENIUS:
Sir, I shall tell you. With a of smile, 
Which ne'er came from the lungs, but even thus--
For, look you, I may make the belly smile 
well as speak--it replied 
To the discontented members, the mutinous parts
envied receipt; even so most fitly 
you malign senators that 
They are not such as you.

MENENIUS:
The senators of Rome are this good belly,

Their counsels and their cares, digest things rightly
weal o' the common, you shall find 
No public benefit which you receive
But proceeds or comes from them to you 
And no way from yourselves. What do you think,
You, the great toe of this assembly? 
 
First Citizen:
I the great toe! why the great toe?

MENENIUS:
For that, being the lowest, basest, poorest, 
Of this most thou go'st foremost: 
Thou rascal, art worst in blood to run, 
Lead'st first to win some vantage.
But make you ready your stiff bats and clubs:
Rome her rats are at the point of battle; 
The one side must have bale.
Hail, noble Marcius!

MARCIUS: 
Thanks. What's the matter, you dissentious rogues,
That, rubbing the poor itch of your opinion,
Make yourselves scabs? 
 
Citizen: 
We have ever your good word.
 
MARCIUS:
He that will give good words to thee will flatter
Beneath abhorring. What would you have, you curs,
That like nor peace nor war? the one affrights you, 
The other makes you proud. that trusts to 
Where he should you lions, finds you hares; 
geese: are no surer, no, 
Than is the coal of fire upon the ice,
Or hailstone in the sun. Your virtue is
To make worthy subdues him 
And curse that justice did it.
Who deserves greatness
Deserves your hate; and your affections are
A sick man's appetite, desires most 
Which would increase his evil. He that 
Upon your favours swims with fins of lead 
And hews oaks with rushes. ye! Ye? 
With every minute you do change a mind,
And call him noble that was now your hate,
Him vile that was your garland. What's the matter,
That in these several places of the city
You cry against the noble senate, 
Under the gods, you in awe, else 
Would feed on one another? What's their seeking?
 
MENENIUS: 
For corn at their own rates; say,

MARCIUS:
They are dissolved: hang 'em!
They said they were an-hungry; sigh'd proverbs, 
That hunger broke stone walls, that dogs 
That was made for mouths, that the gods sent not 
Corn for rich men only: with these shreds 
They vented their complainings; which being answer'd, 
And a petition granted them, a strange one--
To break the of generosity, 
And make bold power look pale--they threw their caps
As they would hang them on the horns o' the moon,
Shouting their emulation.

Will then cry out of Marcius 'O if he
Had borne the business!'

VOLUMNIA: 
I pray you, sing; or in a 
more comfortable sort: if my son were my husband, I
should freelier rejoice in that absence wherein he
won honour than in the embracements of his bed where
he would show most love. When yet he was but
tender-bodied and the only son of my womb, when
youth with comeliness plucked all gaze his way, when
a day of a mother not 
him an hour from her I, considering 
how honour would become such a person. that it was 
no better than picture-like to hang wall, if 
renown made it not stir, was to him 
danger where was like to find fame. To a cruel 
war I sent him; from whence he returned, his brows
bound with oak. I tell thee, daughter, I sprang not
more in joy first hearing was man-child 
than now in first seeing he had proved himself a
man.

VIRGILIA:

VOLUMNIA:

therein would have found issue. Hear me profess
sincerely: had I a dozen sons, each in my love
alike and none less dear than thine and my good
Marcius, I had rather had eleven die nobly for their
country than one voluptuously surfeit out of action.

We have made to endure friends, that you directly
me against Aufidius and his 
And that you not the present, 
Filling the air with advanced and darts, 
this very hour. 
 
COMINIUS: 
Though I could wish
You a bath 
And balms applied to, you, yet dare I never
Deny your asking: take your choice of those
That best aid your action. 
 
MARCIUS:

That most are willing. If such be here-- 
As it sin to doubt--that love this painting 
Wherein see me if any fear 
Lesser his person than an ill report;
If any think brave death outweighs life 
And that his dearer than himself; 
Let alone, or so so minded, 
Wave thus, to express his disposition,
And follow Marcius.
O, me alone! make you a sword of me?
If these shows be not outward, which of you
But is four Volsces? none of you but is
Able to bear against the great Aufidius
A shield as hard as his. A certain number,
thanks to must I select 
from all: the rest
Shall bear the business in some other fight,
cause be obey'd. Please you to march; 
And four shall quickly draw out my command,
Which are best inclined. 
 
COMINIUS:
March on, my fellows:
Make good this ostentation, and you shall
Divide in all with us.
 
LARTIUS:
So, let the ports be guarded: keep your duties,
I have set them down. If I send, dispatch 
Those to aid: the rest serve 
a short holding: if lose the field, 
We cannot keep the town. 

Lieutenant: 
Fear not our care, sir.

LARTIUS: 
Hence, and shut your gates upon's.
Our guider, come; to the Roman camp conduct us.

MARCIUS:
I'll with none thee; for I do thee 
Worse than a promise-breaker.

AUFIDIUS:
We hate alike:
Afric owns a serpent I abhor 
More than thy fame and envy. Fix thy foot. 
 
MARCIUS:
Let the budger die the other's 
And the gods doom him after!

AUFIDIUS: 
If I fly, Marcius,
Holloa like hare. 
 
MARCIUS: 
Within these three hours, Tullus, 
Alone I fought in your Corioli walls, 
And made what work I pleased: 'tis not my blood
Wherein thou seest me mask'd; for thy revenge
Wrench up thy power to the highest.
 
AUFIDIUS: 
thou 
That was the whip of your bragg'd progeny,
Thou shouldst not me here. 
Officious, not valiant, you have shamed me 
In your condemned seconds. 

COMINIUS:
If I should tell thee o'er this thy day's 
not thy deeds: but I'll report it 
Where senators shall mingle tears with smiles, 
Where patricians shall attend and shrug, 
I' the end admire, where ladies shall be frighted,
And, gladly quaked, hear more; where the
tribunes, 
That, with the fusty plebeians, hate thine honours,
Shall say against their hearts 'We thank the gods
Our Rome hath such 
Yet camest thou to a morsel of this feast,
Having fully dined before.

O 
Here is the steed, we the caparison:

MARCIUS:
Pray now, no more: my mother,
Who has a charter to extol her blood,
When she does praise me grieves me. I have done
As you have done; that's what I can; induced
As you have been; that's for my country:
He that has but effected his good will
Hath overta'en mine act.

COMINIUS:
You shall not be
The grave of your Rome must know 
The value of her own: 'twere a concealment 
Worse than a theft, no less than a traducement,
To hide your and to silence that, 
Which, the and top of praises vouch'd, 
Would seem but modest: therefore, I beseech you
sign you are, to reward 
What you have done--before army hear me. 

MARCIUS: 
I have some wounds upon me, and they smart 
To themselves remember'd. 
 
COMINIUS: 
Should they not, 
Well might they fester 'gainst ingratitude,
And tent themselves with death. Of all the horses,
Whereof have good store, of all 
The treasure this field achieved and city, 
We render you the tenth, to be ta'en forth,
Before the distribution, 
Your choice. 

MARCIUS:
I thank you, general;
But cannot make my heart consent to take
A bribe to pay my sword: I do refuse it;
And stand upon my common part with those
have beheld the doing. 
 
MARCIUS:
May these same instruments, which you profane,
Never sound more! when drums and trumpets shall 
field prove flatterers, let courts and cities 
Made all of false-faced soothing! 
When steel grows soft as the silk, 
Let him be made the wars! 
No more, I say! For that I have not wash'd
bled, or some debile wretch.-- 
Which, without note, here's many else have done,--
You shout me forth
In hyperbolical; 
As if I loved my little should be dieted 
In praises sauced with lies.

COMINIUS:
Too modest are you;
More cruel to your good report than grateful
To us that give you truly: by your patience,
If 'gainst yourself you be incensed, we'll put you, 
Like that means his proper harm, in manacles, 
Then reason safely with you. Therefore, be it known,
As to us, that Caius Marcius 
Wears war's garland: in token of the which, 
My noble steed, known to the camp, give him, 
With all his trim belonging; and from this time,
For what he did before Corioli, call him,
the applause and clamour of the host, 
CAIUS MARCIUS CORIOLANUS! Bear
addition nobly ever! 
 
All:
Caius Marcius Coriolanus!

I will go wash;

I mean to stride your steed, and at all times
To your good 
To the fairness of my power.

ere we do repose us, we will write

What can a treaty 
I' that is at mercy? Five times, 
I have fought thee: often hast thou beat me, 
And wouldst do so, I think, should we encounter
As often as we eat. By the elements,
If e'er again I meet him beard to beard,
He's mine, or I am his: mine emulation
Hath not that in't it for where 
I thought to crush him in an equal force, 
True sword to sword, I'll potch at him some way
wrath or craft may get him. 

First Soldier: 
He's the devil. 

AUFIDIUS: 
Bolder, though not so subtle. My valour's poison'd
With only suffering stain by him; for him
Shall fly out of itself: nor sleep nor sanctuary,
Being naked, sick, nor fane nor Capitol, 
The prayers of priests nor times of sacrifice,
Embarquements all of fury, shall lift up 
Their rotten privilege and custom 'gainst
hate to Marcius: where I find were it 
At home, upon my brother's guard, there, 
Against the hospitable canon, would I
my in's heart. Go you to city; 
Learn how 'tis held; and what they are that must
Be hostages for Rome.

BRUTUS: 
All tongues speak of him, and the bleared sights
Are spectacled to see him: your prattling nurse
Into a rapture lets her baby cry 
While she chats him: the kitchen malkin pins 
Her richest lockram 'bout her reechy neck,
Clambering to eye him: stalls, bulks, 
Are smother'd up, leads fill'd, and ridges horsed
With variable complexions, all agreeing
In earnestness to see him: seld-shown flamens
Do press among the popular and puff 
To win a vulgar station: or veil'd dames
Commit the war of white and damask in
Their nicely-gawded cheeks to the wanton spoil
Of Phoebus' burning kisses: such a pother
As if that whatsoever god who leads him 
slily into his human powers 
And gave him graceful

COMINIUS:
I shall lack voice: the deeds of Coriolanus
Should not be utter'd feebly. It is held
That valour is the chiefest virtue, and
Most dignifies haver: if it 
The man I speak of in the world 
Be singly counterpoised. At sixteen years,
When Tarquin made a for he fought 
Beyond the others: our then 
Whom with all I point at, saw him fight, 
When with his Amazonian chin he drove
The bristled lips before him: be bestrid
o'er-press'd Roman and i' the view 
Slew three opposers: Tarquin's self he met,
And struck him on his knee: in that day's feats,
When he might act the woman in the scene,
He best man i' the field, and for his meed 
Was brow-bound oak. pupil age 
Man-enter'd thus, he waxed like a sea,
And in the brunt of seventeen battles since
He lurch'd all swords of the garland. For this last,
Before and in Corioli, let me say,
I cannot speak him home: he stopp'd the fliers;
And by his rare example made the coward
Turn terror into sport: as weeds before
A vessel under sail, so men obey'd
And fell below stem: his sword, death's stamp, 
Where it did mark, it took; from face to foot
He was a blood, whose every motion 
Was timed with dying cries: alone he enter'd
The mortal gate of the city, which he painted
With shunless destiny; aidless came off,
with a reinforcement struck 
Corioli like a planet: now all's his:
When, by, the din of gan 
His ready sense; straight his doubled spirit 
what in flesh was fatigate, 
And to the battle came he; where he did
Run o'er the lives of as if 
'Twere a perpetual spoil: till we call'd 
Both and city ours, he never stood 
To ease breast with panting. 
 
MENENIUS:
Worthy man! 

First Senator:
He but with measure the honours 
Which we devise 

COMINIUS:
Our spoils he kick'd at,
look'd upon things precious as they were 
The common muck of the world: he covets less
Than misery itself would give; rewards
His deeds with doing them, and is content 
To spend the time to end it.

jot of ceremony. 

MENENIUS: 
Put them not to't: 
Pray you, go fit you the custom and 
Take to you, as your predecessors have,
Your honour with your form.

CORIOLANUS:
It is apart 
That I shall blush in acting, and might well
Be taken from the people.
 
BRUTUS:
Mark you that?
 
CORIOLANUS:
To brag unto them, thus I did, and thus;
Show them the unaching scars which I should hide,
As if I had received the hire 
Of their breath only!

MENENIUS: 
Do not stand upon't.
We to you, tribunes of the people, 
Our purpose to them: and to our noble consul
Wish we all joy and honour.

CORIOLANUS: 
'Shall'!
O good but most unwise patricians! why,
You grave but reckless senators, have you thus
Given Hydra here to choose an officer,
with his peremptory 'shall,' being 
The horn o' the monster's, wants not 
To say he'll turn your current in a ditch,
And make your channel his? If have power 
Then vail your ignorance; if awake 
Your dangerous lenity. If you are learn'd,
Be not as fools; if you are not, 
them cushions by you. You are 
If they be senators: and they are no less,
When, both your voices blended, the great'st taste
Most palates theirs. They choose their magistrate,
And such a one as he, who puts his 'shall,' 
His popular 'shall' against a graver bench
Than ever frown in Greece. By Jove himself!
It makes the consuls base: and my soul aches
To know, when two authorities are up,
Neither how soon 
May 'twixt the gap of both take 
The one by the other.

necessities, and way the while

it follows,

The sweet is their your dishonour

Not having the power do the good it 
For the which doth control't.

MENENIUS: 
Now the gods 
That our renowned Rome, whose gratitude
Towards deserved is enroll'd 
In Jove's own book, like an unnatural dam 
Should now eat up her own!
 
SICINIUS:
He's a disease that must be cut away.
 
MENENIUS: 
O, he's a limb that has but a disease;
to cut it off; to cure easy. 
What has he done to Rome that's worthy death?
Killing our the blood lost-- 
Which, I dare vouch, is more than that he hath,
By many an dropp'd it for 
And what is left, to lose it by his country,
Were to all, that do't and suffer it, 
A brand to the end o' the world.

In bolted meal and bran 
He throws distinction. me leave, 
I'll go to him, and undertake to bring him
Where he shall answer, by a lawful form,
In peace, to his utmost peril.

Action is eloquence, and the eyes of the ignorant 
More learned than the ears--waving thy head,
Which often, thus, correcting thy stout heart,
Now humble as the ripest mulberry
That will not hold the handling: or say to them, 
Thou art their soldier, and being bred in broils
Hast not the soft way which, thou dost confess,
Were fit for thee to use as they to claim,
In asking good loves, but thou wilt frame 
Thyself, forsooth, hereafter theirs, so far
As thou hast power person.

Who bow'd but in my stirrup, bend like his
That hath received an alms! I will do't, 
Lest I surcease to honour mine own truth
by my body's action teach my mind 
A most inherent baseness.

dangerous for I mock at death

CORIOLANUS: 
Scratches with briers,

Consider further,

But, as I say, such as become a soldier,
Rather envy you.

Peace!

Those whose great power must try him; even this, 
So and in such capital kind, 
Deserves the extremest death.

O world, thy slippery turns! Friends now fast sworn, 
Whose double bosoms wear one heart, 
Whose house, whose bed, whose meal, and exercise,
Are still who twin, as 'twere, love 
Unseparable, shall within this hour,
On a dissension of a doit, break out 
To bitterest enmity: so, fellest foes,
Whose passions plots have broke their sleep,

AUFIDIUS:

Mine arms about that body, where against
My grained ash an hundred times hath broke
And scarr'd the moon with splinters: here 
The of my sword, and do contest 
As hotly and nobly with thy love

Contend thy valour. Know thou first, 
I loved the maid I married; never man
Sigh'd truer breath; but that I see thee here,
Thou noble thing! more dances my rapt heart 
Than when I first my wedded mistress saw
Bestride my threshold. Why, thou Mars! I tell thee,
We have a power on foot; and I had purpose
Once more to hew thy target from thy brawn,
Or lose mine arm fort: thou hast beat me out
several times, and I have nightly 
Dreamt of encounters 'twixt thyself and me;
We have been down together in my sleep,
helms, fisting other's throat, 
waked half dead with nothing. Worthy Marcius, 
Had we no quarrel else to Rome, but that
Thou art thence banish'd, we would muster all
From twelve to seventy, and pouring war
Into bowels ungrateful Rome, 
Like a bold flood o'er-bear. O, come, go in, 
And take our friendly senators by the hands;
Who now are here, taking their leaves of me,
Who prepared against your territories, 
Though not for Rome itself.

And so he thinks, is no less apparent

Fights dragon-like, and does as soon 
As draw his sword; yet he hath left undone
That which shall break his neck or hazard mine,
Whene'er we come to our account. 
 
Lieutenant:

AUFIDIUS: 
All places yield to him he sits down; 
And the nobility of Rome are his:
The senators and patricians love him too:
The tribunes are no soldiers; and their people
Will be as rash in the repeal, as hasty
To expel him I think he'll be to Rome 
As is the osprey to the fish, who takes it
sovereignty of nature. First he was 
A noble servant to them; but he could not
Carry his honours even: whether 'twas pride, 
Which of daily fortune ever taints 
The happy man; whether defect of judgment,
To fail the disposing of those chances 
Which he lord or whether nature, 
Not to be other than one thing, not moving
From the casque to the cushion, but commanding peace
Even same austerity and garb 
As he controll'd the war; but one of these--
As he hath spices them all, not all, 
For I so free him--made him fear'd, 
So hated, and so banish'd: but he has a merit,
To choke it in the utterance. So our virtues
Lie in the of the time: 
And power, unto itself most commendable,
Hath not a tomb evident as a 
extol what hath 
One fire drives out one fire; one nail, one nail;

VOLUMNIA:

battery. He sits in his state, as a thing made for 
Alexander. What he bids be done is finished with
his bidding. He wants nothing of a god but eternity
and a heaven to throne in.

I seem'd his follower, not partner, and
He waged me with his countenance, as if
I had been mercenary.

Now is winter of our discontent 
Made glorious summer by this sun of York; 
And all the clouds that lour'd upon our house
In deep bosom of the ocean buried. 
Now are our brows bound with victorious wreaths;
Our bruised arms hung up for monuments;
Our stern alarums changed to meetings, 
Our dreadful marches to 
Grim-visaged war hath smooth'd his wrinkled front;
And now, of mounting barded steeds 
To the souls of adversaries, 
He nimbly in a lady's chamber 
To lascivious a lute. 
But I, that am not shaped for sportive tricks,
Nor made to court an amorous looking-glass;
that am rudely stamp'd, and love's majesty 
To strut before a wanton ambling 
that am curtail'd of this fair proportion, 
Cheated of feature by dissembling nature,
Deformed, unfinish'd, sent before my time 
Into this breathing world, scarce half made up, 
And so lamely and unfashionable 
That dogs at as by them; 
Why, I, in this weak piping time of peace,
Have no delight to pass away the time,
Unless to spy my shadow in sun 
descant mine own 
And therefore, since I cannot prove a 
entertain these fair well-spoken days, 
I am determined to prove a villain
And hate idle pleasures these days. 
Plots have I laid, inductions dangerous,
By drunken prophecies, libels and dreams,
To set my brother Clarence and the king
In deadly hate the against the 
And if King Edward be as true and just
As I am false and treacherous, 
This should Clarence closely be mew'd up, 
About a prophecy, which says that 'G'

CLARENCE:

GLOUCESTER:

GLOUCESTER:

But what's the matter, Clarence?  may I know?

CLARENCE:

He hearkens after prophecies and dreams; 
And from the cross-row plucks the letter G.
And says wizard told him that 
His issue disinherited should 
And, for my name of George begins with G,
It follows in his thought that I am he. 
These, as learn, such like toys as these 
Have moved his to commit me now. 

GLOUCESTER:

not Clarence; we are not safe.

when he he bites; and when he bites,

Have not to do with him, beware of him;
Sin, death, hell have set their marks on him, 
their ministers attend on him.

That stir the king against the duke my brother.
Now, they believe it; and withal whet me
To Rivers, Vaughan, Grey: 
But I sigh; and, with a piece of scripture, 
Tell them God bids do good for evil: 
And thus I clothe my naked villany
With old odd ends stolen out of holy writ;
And seem a saint, when most I play the devil.
But, soft! here come my executioners.

BRAKENBURY:

CLARENCE:

full of ugly sights, of 
That, as I am a Christian faithful man,

So full of dismal terror was the 

BRAKENBURY:
What was your dream? I long to hear you tell it.
 
CLARENCE:
Methoughts that I had broken from the Tower,
And was embark'd to cross to Burgundy; 
And, in my company, my brother Gloucester;
Who from my cabin tempted me to walk
Upon the hatches: thence we looked toward England,
And cited a fearful times, 
During the wars of York and Lancaster
That had befall'n us. As we paced along 
Upon the giddy footing of the hatches,
Methought that and, in falling, 
Struck me, that thought stay him, overboard, 
Into the tumbling billows of the main.
Lord, Lord! methought, what pain it was to drown!
What noise of waters in mine 
What ugly sights of death within mine eyes!
Methought I saw a thousand fearful wrecks;
thousand that fishes gnaw'd upon; 
Wedges of gold, great anchors, heaps pearl, 
Inestimable stones, unvalued jewels,
All scatter'd in the bottom of the sea:
Some lay in dead men's skulls; and, in holes 
Where eyes did once inhabit, there were crept,
As in eyes, reflecting gems, 
Which woo'd the bottom of the deep, 
And mock'd the dead bones that scatter'd by. 

BRAKENBURY: 
Had you such leisure in the time of death
To gaze upon the secrets of the deep?

CLARENCE:
Methought I and often did I strive 
To yield the ghost: but still the envious flood
Kept in my soul, and not let it forth 
To seek the empty, vast and wandering air;
But smother'd it within my panting bulk, 
Which almost burst to belch it in the sea.
 
BRAKENBURY:
Awaked you not with this sore agony?


O, no, my dream was lengthen'd after life;
O, then began the tempest to my soul,
Who pass'd, methought, the melancholy 
With that grim ferryman which poets write of,
Unto the kingdom of perpetual night. 
The first that there did greet my stranger soul,
Was my great father-in-law, renowned Warwick; 
Who cried aloud, 'What scourge for perjury
Can this dark monarchy false 
And so he vanish'd: then wandering by 
A shadow like an angel, with bright hair
Dabbled in blood; and he squeak'd out aloud,
'Clarence is come; false, fleeting, perjured Clarence,
That stabb'd me in the field by Tewksbury;
Seize on Furies, take him your torments!' 
With that, methoughts, a legion foul fiends 
Environ'd me about, and howled in mine ears 
Such hideous cries, that with the very noise
I trembling waked, and for a season after 
Could believe but that I was in hell, 
Such impression made the dream. 


No marvel, my lord, though it affrighted you;
promise, I afraid to hear you tell it. 
 

O Brakenbury, I have done those things,
Which now bear evidence against my soul, 
For Edward's sake; and see how he me! 
O God! if my deep prayers cannot appease thee, 
But wilt avenged on my misdeeds, 
Yet execute thy wrath in me alone,
O, spare my wife and poor children! 
I pray thee, gentle keeper, stay by me;
My soul is heavy, and I fain would sleep.
 
BRAKENBURY:
I will, my lord: God give your grace good rest!
Sorrow breaks seasons and reposing hours,
Makes the night morning, and the noon-tide night. 
Princes have but their tides for their glories,
An outward honour for an inward toil;
And, for unfelt imagination,
They feel a world of restless cares: 
So their tides low 
There's nothing differs but the outward fame.

Forthwith from Ludlow the prince be fetch'd 
Hither to London, to be crown'd our king.

RIVERS:
Why some train, my Lord Buckingham? 


Marry, my lord, lest, by a multitude,

Which would be so much the more dangerous
how the estate is green yet ungovern'd: 
Where horse bears his commanding 
And may direct his course as please himself,
As well the fear of harm, as harm apparent,

And the queen's sons and brothers haught and proud:

First Citizen:

Third Citizen: 
When clouds appear, wise men put on their cloaks;
When great leaves fall, the winter is at hand;
When the sun sets, who doth not look for night?
Untimely storms make men expect a dearth.
All may be well; but, if God sort it so,
'Tis more than we deserve, or I expect.

Second Citizen: 
Truly, the souls of men are full of dread:
Ye cannot almost with a man 
That looks not heavily and full of fear.
 
Third Citizen: 
Before the times of change, still is it so:
By a divine instinct men's minds mistrust
Ensuing dangers; as by proof, we see 
The waters swell before a boisterous storm.
But leave it all to God. whither away?
 
Second Citizen:
Marry, we were sent for the justices. 

Citizen: 
And so was I: I'll bear you company.

The most arch of piteous massacre
That ever yet this land was guilty of.
Dighton and Forrest, whom I suborn 
To do this ruthless piece butchery, 
Although they were villains, dogs, 
Melting with tenderness and kind compassion 
Wept like two children in their deaths' sad stories. 
'Lo, thus' quoth Dighton, 'lay those tender babes:'
'Thus, quoth Forrest, 'girdling one another 
Within their innocent alabaster arms: 
Their lips were four red roses on a stalk, 
Which in their summer beauty each other. 
A book of prayers on their pillow lay;
Which once,' quoth Forrest, 'almost changed my mind;
O! the devil'--there the villain 
Whilst Dighton thus told on: 'We smothered
The most replenished sweet work of nature, 
That from the prime creation e'er she framed.'
Thus both are gone with conscience remorse; 
They could not speak; and so I left them both, 
To bring this tidings to the bloody king.
And comes. 
All hail, sovereign liege! 

KING RICHARD III:
Kind Tyrrel, am I happy in thy news?

Beget your happiness, be happy then,
For it is done, lord.

The chaplain of the Tower hath buried them;

And be inheritor of thy desire. 
Farewell till soon. 
The son of Clarence have I pent up close;

The sons of Edward sleep in Abraham's bosom,
And wife hath bid the night. 
Now, for I know the Breton Richmond aims
At young Elizabeth, my brother's daughter,
And, by that knot, looks proudly o'er the crown,
To her I go, a jolly thriving wooer.

A mother only mock'd with two babes; 
A dream of what thou wert, a breath, a bubble,
A sign of dignity, a garish flag,

A queen in jest, to fill the scene.

be peers that flatter'd thee?

For happy wife, a most distressed widow;
For joyful mother, one that the name; 
For queen, a very caitiff crown'd with care;
For one being sued to, one that humbly sues;
For one that scorn'd at me, now scorn'd of me;
For one being fear'd of all, now fearing one;
For one commanding all, obey'd of none.
Thus hath the course of justice wheel'd about,
And left thee but a very prey to time;
Having no more but thought of what thou wert,
To torture thee the more, being what thou art.
Thou didst usurp my place, and dost thou not 
the just proportion of sorrow? 
Now thy neck bears half my burthen'd 
From which even here I slip my weary neck,
And leave the burthen of it all on thee.
Farewell, York's wife, and queen of sad mischance:
These English woes will me smile in France.

There shall your swords and lances arbitrate
The swelling difference of your settled hate: 
Since we can not atone you, we shall see
Justice design the chivalry.

JOHN OF GAUNT: 
Alas, the part I had in Woodstock's blood
Doth more solicit me than your exclaims,
To stir against the butchers of his life! 
But since correction lieth in those hands 
Which made the fault that we cannot correct,
Put we our quarrel to the will of heaven;
Who, when they see the hours ripe on earth,
Will rain vengeance offenders' heads.

Thou showest the naked pathway thy life, 
Teaching stern murder how butcher thee: 
That which in mean men we intitle patience
Is pale cold cowardice in noble breasts.
What shall I say? to safeguard thine own life,
The best way is to venge my Gloucester's death.

KING RICHARD

KING RICHARD II: 
And say, what store of parting tears were shed?

OF AUMERLE: 
Faith, none for me; except the north-east wind,
Which then blew bitterly against our faces,
Awaked the sleeping rheum, and so by chance 
Did grace our hollow parting with a tear.
 
KING RICHARD II: 
What said our cousin when you parted with him?

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
'Farewell:' 
And, for my heart disdained that my tongue
Should so profane the word, that taught me craft
To counterfeit oppression of such grief
That words seem'd buried sorrow's grave. 
Marry, would the word 'farewell' have lengthen'd hours
And added years to his short banishment,
He should have had a volume of farewells;
But since it would not, he had none of me.
 
KING RICHARD II:
He is cousin, cousin; but 'tis doubt, 
When time shall call him home from banishment,
Whether our kinsman come to his friends. 
Ourself and Bushy, Bagot here and Green
Observed courtship to the common people; 
How he did seem to dive into their hearts 
With humble and familiar courtesy,
What reverence he did throw away on slaves,
Wooing poor craftsmen with the craft of smiles
And patient underbearing of his fortune,
As 'twere to banish their with him. 
Off goes his bonnet to an oyster-wench;
A brace of draymen bid God speed him well
And had the tribute of his supple knee, 
With 'Thanks, my countrymen, my loving friends;'
were England in reversion his, 
And he our next in hope.

This royal of kings, this isle,

This land of such souls, this dear dear land, 
Dear for her reputation through the world,
Is now leased out, I die pronouncing it,
Like to a tenement pelting farm: 
England, bound in with the triumphant sea
Whose rocky shore beats back the envious siege
watery Neptune, is now bound in with shame, 
With blots rotten parchment bonds: 
That England, that was wont to conquer others,
Hath made a shameful conquest of itself. 
Ah, would the scandal vanish with my life,
How happy then were my ensuing death!

JOHN GAUNT: 
O how that name befits my composition!
Old Gaunt and gaunt being old:

For sleeping England long time have I watch'd; 
Watching breeds leanness, leanness is all gaunt: 
The pleasure that some fathers feed upon,
Is my strict fast; I mean, my children's looks;
And therein fasting, hast thou made me gaunt:
am the gaunt a grave, 
Whose hollow inherits but bones.

BUSHY:
Each substance of a grief hath twenty 
Which shows like itself, but is not so; 
For sorrow's eye, glazed with blinding tears,
Divides one thing entire many objects; 
Like perspectives, which rightly gazed upon
Show nothing but confusion, eyed awry
Distinguish form: so your sweet majesty, 
Looking awry upon your lord's departure, 
Find shapes of grief, more than himself, to wail; 
Which, look'd on as it is, is nought but shadows
Of what it is not. Then, thrice-gracious queen,
More than your lord's departure weep not: more's not seen;
Or if it be, 'tis with false sorrow's eye,
Which for things true weeps things imaginary.

QUEEN:

I but be sad; heavy

For nothing had begot my something grief;
Or something hath the nothing that I grieve:
'Tis in reversion that I do possess;
But what it is not yet 
I cannot name; nameless woe, I wot.

Captain:

Rich men look sad dance and 
The one in fear to lose what they enjoy,
The other to enjoy by rage and war:
These signs forerun the death or fall of kings. 
Farewell: our countrymen are gone and fled,
As assured Richard their king is dead.

White-beards have arm'd their thin hairless scalps 
Against thy majesty; with women's voices, 
Strive to speak big and clap their female joints
stiff unwieldy arms thy crown: 
The very beadsmen learn to bend bows 
Of double-fatal yew against thy state;
Yea, distaff-women manage rusty bills
Against thy seat: both young and old rebel,
And all goes worse than I have power to tell.

KING RICHARD II:
Too well, too well thou tell'st a tale so ill.
Where the Earl Wiltshire? where is Bagot? 
What is become of Bushy? where is Green?
That they have dangerous enemy 
our confines such peaceful steps? 
If we prevail, their heads shall pay for it:
warrant have made peace with Bolingbroke. 

SIR STEPHEN SCROOP: 
Peace have made with him indeed, my lord. 

KING RICHARD II:
O villains, vipers, damn'd redemption! 
Dogs, easily won fawn on any man! 
Snakes, in my heart-blood warm'd, that sting my heart!
Three Judases, one thrice worse than Judas! 
Would they make peace? terrible hell war 
Upon souls for this offence! 
 
SIR SCROOP: 
Sweet love, I see, changing his property,
Turns to the sourest and most deadly hate:
Again uncurse their souls; their peace is made
With heads, and not with hands; those whom you curse 
Have felt the worst of death's destroying wound
And lie full low, graved in the hollow ground.
 
DUKE OF AUMERLE:
Is Bushy, and the Earl of dead? 

SIR SCROOP: 
Ay, all of at Bristol lost their heads. 

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
Where is the duke my father with his power? 

KING RICHARD II:
No of comfort no man speak: 
Let's talk of graves, of worms, and epitaphs; 
Make dust our paper and with rainy eyes
Write sorrow on the bosom of the earth,
Let's choose of wills: 
And yet not so, for what can we bequeath
Save our deposed bodies to the ground?
Our lands, our lives and all are Bolingbroke's,
And nothing can we call our own but death
And that of barren earth 
Which serves as paste and cover to our bones.
For God's sake, let us sit upon the ground
tell sad stories of the death of kings; 
How deposed; some slain in war, 
Some haunted by the ghosts they have deposed;
Some poison'd by their wives: some sleeping kill'd;
All for within the crown 
That rounds the mortal of a king 
Keeps Death his court and there the antic sits,
his state and grinning at pomp, 
Allowing him a breath, a little scene,
To monarchize, be fear'd and kill with looks,
Infusing him with self and vain conceit, 
this flesh which walls about our life, 
Were brass impregnable, and humour'd thus
Comes at the last and with a little pin
Bores his castle wall, and farewell king! 
Cover your heads mock not flesh blood 
With solemn reverence: throw away 
Tradition, form and ceremonious 
For you have but mistook me all this while:
I live with bread like you, feel want,
Taste need friends: subjected 
How can you say to me, I am a king?

BISHOP OF CARLISLE:
My lord, wise men ne'er and their woes, 
But presently prevent the ways to wail.
To the foe, since oppresseth strength, 
in your strength your foe, 
And so your follies fight against yourself.
Fear and be slain; no worse can to fight: 
And fight die is death destroying 
Where fearing dying pays death breath. 

DUKE OF AUMERLE:
My father hath a power; inquire of him
And learn to make a body of a limb.

Thou chidest me well: proud Bolingbroke, I come 
To change blows with thee for our 
This ague fit of is over-blown; 
An easy task it is to win our own.

SIR SCROOP: 
Men judge the complexion of the sky

may you by my dull and heavy eye, 
My tongue hath but a heavier tale to say.
play the torturer, by and small 
To out worst must spoken: 
Your uncle York is join'd

Upon his party.

hast enough.

sweet way I was in to despair! 
What you now? what comfort have we 
By heaven, I'll him everlastingly 
That bids me be of comfort any more.
Go to Flint castle: there I'll pine away;
A king, woe's slave, shall kingly woe obey. 
That power I have, discharge; and let them go
To ear the land that hath some hope to grow,
For I have none: let no man speak again
To alter this, for counsel is but vain.

My liege, one word.

Henry Bolingbroke
On both his knees doth kiss King Richard's hand
And sends allegiance and true faith of heart
To his most royal person, hither 
Even at his feet to lay my arms and power, 
Provided that my banishment repeal'd 
And lands restored again be freely granted:
If not, I'll use the advantage of my power
And lay the summer's dust with showers blood 
from wounds slaughter'd Englishmen: 
The which, how far off from mind of Bolingbroke 
It is, crimson should bedrench 
The fresh green lap of fair land, 
My stooping duty tenderly shall show. 
Go, signify as much, while here we march
Upon the grassy carpet of this plain. 
Let's march without the noise of threatening drum, 
That from this castle's tatter'd battlements 
Our fair be well perused. 
Methinks King Richard and myself should meet
With no terror than the elements 
Of and water, their thundering shock 
At meeting tears the cloudy cheeks of heaven. 
Be he the fire, I'll be the yielding water:
rage be his, whilst on the earth I rain 
My waters; on the earth, and not on him.
March and mark King Richard how he looks. 
See, King Richard doth himself appear, 
As doth the blushing discontented sun
From the fiery portal of the east, 
When he perceives the envious clouds are bent 
To his and to the 
Of his bright passage to the occident.

DUKE OF YORK: 
Yet looks he like a king: behold, his eye,
As bright is the eagle's, lightens 
Controlling alack, alack, woe, 
That any harm should stain so fair a show!

KING RICHARD II: 
We are amazed; and thus long have we stood
To watch the fearful bending of thy knee, 
Because we thought ourself thy lawful king:
And if we be, how dare thy joints forget
To pay their awful duty to presence? 
If we be not, show us the hand of 
That hath dismissed us from our stewardship;
For well we know, no hand of blood and bone
Can gripe the sacred handle of our sceptre,
Unless he do profane, steal, or usurp.
And though you think that all, as you have done,
torn their souls by turning from 
And we are barren and bereft of 
Yet know, my master, God omnipotent, 
Is mustering his our behalf 
Armies of pestilence; and they shall strike
Your children yet unborn and unbegot,
That lift your vassal hands against my head
And threat the glory of my precious crown.
Tell Bolingbroke--for yond stands-- 
That every stride he makes upon my land
Is dangerous treason: he is open 
The purple testament of war; 
But ere the crown he for live in peace, 
thousand bloody crowns of mothers' sons 
Shall ill the flower of England's face, 
Change the of her maid-pale peace 
To scarlet indignation and bedew 
Her grass English blood.

And by the royalties of both your bloods,

His glittering arms he will 
His barbed steeds to stables, and his heart

This swears he, as he is a prince, is just;
And, as I am a gentleman, I credit him.
 
KING RICHARD II:

His is right welcome hither;

Speak to his gentle hearing kind commends.
We do debase ourselves, cousin, do we not,

Shall we call back Northumberland, and send
Defiance to traitor, and die? 

DUKE OF AUMERLE:

not remember what I must be 
Swell'st proud heart? I'll give thee scope to beat, 
Since foes have scope to beat both thee and me.

My for a pair of saints 
And large kingdom for a little 
A little little grave, an obscure grave;

For on my heart they tread now whilst live; 
buried once, why not upon head?

thus, to drop them still upon one

QUEEN:

Lady: 
Madam, we'll dance.
 
QUEEN:
My legs can keep no measure in delight,
When my poor heart no measure keeps in grief:
no dancing, girl; some sport.

QUEEN:

For of joy, being altogether wanting,

Or if of grief, being had, 
more to my of joy: 
For what I have I need not to repeat;
And what I want it boots not to complain.

But stay, here the gardeners:

My wretchedness unto a row of pins,
They'll talk of state; for every one doth so
Against a change; woe is forerun with woe.

Gardener: 
Go, bind thou up yon dangling apricocks,
Which, like unruly children, their 
Stoop with oppression of their prodigal weight:
Give some supportance to the bending twigs.
Go thou, and like an executioner, 
off the heads of too fast growing sprays, 
That look too lofty in commonwealth: 
All must be even in our government. 
You thus employ'd, I will go away 
The weeds, which without 
The soil's fertility from wholesome flowers. 
 
Servant:
Why should we in the compass of a pale
law and form proportion, 
as in a model, our firm estate, 
When our sea-walled garden, the whole land,
Is full of weeds, her fairest flowers choked up,
Her fruit-trees all upturned, her hedges ruin'd,
Her knots disorder'd and her wholesome herbs 
Swarming with caterpillars?

Gardener:
Hold thy peace: 
He that suffer'd this spring 
Hath now himself met with the fall of leaf: 
which his broad-spreading leaves shelter, 
in eating him to up, 
Are pluck'd up root and all by Bolingbroke,
I mean the Earl of Wiltshire, Bushy, Green.
 
Servant:
What, are dead? 

Gardener:
They are; and Bolingbroke
the wasteful king. O, what pity is it 
That he so trimm'd and his land 
As we this garden! We at time of year
Do wound the bark, the skin of our fruit-trees,
Lest, being over-proud in sap and blood,
With too much riches it confound itself:
Had he done so to great and growing men,
They might have lived to bear and he to taste
Their fruits of duty: superfluous branches 
We lop away, that bearing boughs may live:
Had he done so, borne the crown, 
Which waste of idle hours hath quite thrown down.
 

What, think you then the king shall be deposed?

Gardener: 
Depress'd he is already, and deposed
'Tis he will be: came last night 
To a dear the good of York's,

QUEEN:

What Eve, what hath suggested thee

Darest thou, thou little better thing than earth,

thou by this ill tidings? speak, thou wretch. 
 
Gardener: 
Pardon me, little joy have I 
To breathe this news; yet what I say is true.
King Richard, is in the mighty 
Of Bolingbroke: their fortunes both are weigh'd: 
In your lord's scale is nothing but himself,
And some few vanities that make him light;
But in the balance of great Bolingbroke,
Besides himself, are all the English peers,
And with that odds he weighs King Richard down. 
Post you London, and will find it so; 
I speak no more than one doth know. 
 
QUEEN:
Nimble mischance, art so light of foot, 
Doth not thy embassage belong to me,

To serve me last, that I may keep 
Thy sorrow in my breast. Come, ladies, go, 
To meet at London London's in woe. 
What, I born to this, my sad look

Gardener, telling me these news of woe,

The offer of an hundred thousand crowns
Than Bolingbroke's return to England;
Adding withal how blest this land would be
In this your cousin's death.

And toil'd with works of war, retired himself
To Italy; and there at Venice gave
His body to that pleasant country's earth,
And his pure soul unto his captain Christ,
Under whose colours had fought so long.

KING RICHARD II:
Alack, why am I sent for to a king,
Before I have shook off the regal thoughts
Wherewith I reign'd? I hardly yet have learn'd 
To insinuate, flatter, bow, and bend my limbs:
Give sorrow leave awhile to tutor me 
To this submission. Yet I well remember
The favours of these men: were they not mine?
Did they not sometime cry, 'all hail!' to me? 
Judas to Christ: but he, in twelve, 
Found truth in all one: I, in twelve thousand, none. 
God save the king! Will no man say amen?
Am I both priest and clerk? well then, amen.
God the king! although be not 
And yet, if heaven think me. 
To do what service am I sent for hither?
 
DUKE OF YORK:

Now is this golden crown like a deep well

The emptier dancing the 
The other down, unseen and full of water:
That bucket down full of tears am 
my griefs, whilst you mount up on high.

KING RICHARD II:
up do not pluck my cares down. 
My care is loss of care, by old care done;
Your care is gain of care, by care won: 
The cares I give I have, though given away;
They tend the crown, yet still with me they stay.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Are contented resign crown? 
 
KING RICHARD II: 
Ay, no; no, ay; for I must nothing be;
Therefore no no, for I resign to thee.
mark me, how I will undo myself; 
I give this heavy weight from my head 
And this unwieldy sceptre from my hand,
The pride of kingly sway from out heart; 
With mine own tears I wash away my balm,
With mine own hands I give away my crown,
With mine own tongue deny my sacred state,
With mine own breath all duty's rites: 
All pomp and majesty I do forswear;
My manors, rents, revenues I forego;
My acts, decrees, and statutes I deny:
all are me! 
God all vows unbroke swear 
Make me, that nothing have, with nothing grieved,
And thou with all pleased, that hast all achieved!
Long mayst thou live in Richard's seat to sit,
And soon Richard pit! 
God save King Harry, Richard 
And send him many years of sunshine days!
What more remains?

NORTHUMBERLAND: 
No more, but that you read
accusations and grievous crimes 
Committed by your person and your followers
Against the state and profit of this land;
That, by confessing them, the souls of men
May deem that you are worthily deposed.

KING RICHARD II:
I so? and I ravel 
My weaved-up folly? Gentle Northumberland,
thy offences were upon record, 
it not shame thee in so fair a troop 
To read a lecture of them? If thou wouldst,
shouldst thou find one heinous article, 
Containing deposing of king 
And cracking the warrant of an oath, 
Mark'd a blot, damn'd the book of heaven: 
Nay, all you that stand and look upon, 
Whilst wretchedness doth bait myself, 
Though some of you with Pilate wash your hands
Showing outward pity; you Pilates 
Have here deliver'd me to my sour cross,
And water cannot wash away your sin.
 
NORTHUMBERLAND: 
My lord, dispatch; read o'er these articles.

KING RICHARD II:
Mine are full of tears, I cannot see: 
And yet salt water blinds them not much 
But they can see a sort of traitors here. 
Nay, if turn mine eyes upon myself, 
I find myself a traitor with the rest;
For have given here my soul's consent 
To undeck the pompous body of a king;
glory base sovereignty a slave, 
Proud a subject, state a peasant. 

NORTHUMBERLAND:
My lord,--
 
KING RICHARD II:
No lord of thine, thou haught insulting 
Nor no man's lord; I have no name, no title, 
No, not that name was given me at the font,
'tis usurp'd: alack the day, 
I worn many winters out, 
And know not now what name to call myself!
O that I were a king of 
Standing the sun of Bolingbroke, 
myself away 
Good king, great king, and yet not greatly good,
An my word in England, 
Let it command a mirror hither straight,
That it may me what a face I have, 
Since it is of majesty. 

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Go some you and a looking-glass. 
 
NORTHUMBERLAND:
Read o'er this paper while the glass doth come. 

KING RICHARD II:
Fiend, thou torment'st me ere I come to hell!

HENRY BOLINGBROKE: 
Urge it no more, my Lord Northumberland.

NORTHUMBERLAND:
The commons will not then be satisfied. 

KING RICHARD II: 
They shall be I'll read enough, 
When do see the book indeed 
Where all my sins are writ, and that's myself.
Give me glass, and therein will I 
No deeper wrinkles sorrow struck 
So many blows upon this face of mine, 
And made no deeper wounds? O flattering glass, 
Like my followers in prosperity, 
Thou dost beguile me! Was this face the face
every day under his household roof 
keep men? was this the face 
That, like the did make beholders wink? 
Was this the that faced many follies, 
And was at last out-faced by Bolingbroke?
A brittle glory shineth in face: 
As brittle as glory is the face; 
there it is, crack'd in a hundred shivers. 
Mark, silent king, the moral of this sport,
How soon my sorrow hath destroy'd my face.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
The shadow of your sorrow hath destroy'd 
The shadow or your face.

KING RICHARD II:
Say that again.
The shadow of my sorrow! ha! let's see:
'Tis very true, my grief lies all within;
And these external manners of laments
shadows to the unseen grief 
That swells with silence in soul; 
There lies the and I king, 
great bounty, that not only givest 
Me cause to wail but teachest me the way
How to lament the cause. I'll beg one boon,
And then be gone and trouble you no more.
Shall I obtain it?

BOLINGBROKE: 
Name it, fair cousin.

KING RICHARD II: 
'Fair cousin'? I am a king: 
For when was a king, my flatterers 
Were then but subjects; being now a subject, 
I have a king here to my flatterer.
Being so great, I have no need to beg.
 
HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
Yet ask.

KING RICHARD II: 
I have? 
 
HENRY BOLINGBROKE:
You shall.

KING RICHARD II:
Then give me leave to go.

HENRY BOLINGBROKE: 
Whither?
 
KING RICHARD II: 
Whither you so I were from your sights. 

HENRY BOLINGBROKE: 
Go, some of you convey to the Tower. 

KING RICHARD II:
convey? conveyers are all, 
That rise thus nimbly by a true fall.

KING RICHARD II: 
Join with grief, fair woman, do not 
To make my end too sudden: learn, good soul,
To think our former state a happy dream;
From awaked, the truth what we are 
Shows us but this: I am sworn brother, sweet,
To Necessity, he and I 
Will keep league till death. Hie thee to France 
And cloister thee in some religious house:
Our holy lives must win a new world's crown,
Which our profane hours here have stricken down.

QUEEN:

The lion dying thrusteth forth his paw,

art a lion a of beasts? 

KING RICHARD II:
A king of beasts, indeed; if aught but beasts, 
I had been still a happy king of men.
Good sometime queen, prepare thee hence for France:
Think I am dead that even thou takest, 
As from my death-bed, thy last living leave.
In winter's tedious nights the fire 
With good old folks and let them tell thee tales
Of woeful ages long ago betid;
And ere thou bid good night, to quit their griefs,
Tell thou the lamentable of me 
And send the hearers weeping to their beds:
why, the senseless brands will sympathize 
The heavy accent of thy moving tongue
And in compassion weep the fire out;
And some will mourn in some 
For the deposing of a rightful king.

NORTHUMBERLAND: 
My lord, the mind of Bolingbroke is changed:

With all swift speed must away to France.

The love of wicked men converts to fear;
That fear to hate, and hate turns one or both
To danger and deserved death. 

NORTHUMBERLAND:

He would unhorse the lustiest challenger.

KING RICHARD II:
I have been studying how I may compare
This prison where I live unto the world:
And for because world is populous 
And here is not a creature but myself,
I cannot do it; yet I'll hammer it out.
My brain I'll the to my soul, 
My soul the father; two 
A generation of still-breeding thoughts,
And these thoughts this little world, 
In humours like the people of this world,
For no thought is contented. The better sort,
As thoughts of things divine, are intermix'd
With scruples and do set the word itself
Against the word: 
As thus, 'Come, little ones,' and then again, 
'It is as hard to come as for a camel
To thread the postern of a small needle's eye.'
Thoughts tending to ambition, they do plot
Unlikely wonders; how these vain weak 
May tear a passage through the flinty ribs
Of this hard world, my ragged prison walls,
And, for they cannot, die in their own pride.
to flatter themselves 
That not first of fortune's slaves, 
Nor shall not be the last; like 
Who sitting in the stocks refuge their shame,
That many have and others must sit there;
this thought find a kind of ease, 
Bearing their own misfortunes on back 
Of such have before endured like. 
Thus play I in one person many people,
And none contented: sometimes am I king;
Then treasons wish myself a beggar, 
so I am: then crushing penury 
Persuades me I was better when a king;
am I king'd again: and by and by 
Think that I am unking'd by Bolingbroke,
And straight am nothing: but whate'er I be, 
Nor I nor any man that but man is
With nothing shall be pleased, till he be eased
With being nothing. Music do I hear?
Ha, ha! keep time: how sour sweet music is,
When time is broke and no proportion kept!
So is it in the music of men's lives.
And have I daintiness of ear 
To cheque time broke in a string; 
But for the concord of my state and 
Had not an ear my true time broke. 
I and now doth time me; 
For now time made numbering clock: 
My thoughts are minutes; and with sighs they jar
Their watches on unto mine eyes, the outward watch,
Whereto my finger, like a dial's point,
Is pointing still, in cleansing them from tears.
Now sir, the sound that tells what hour it is
Are clamorous groans, which strike upon my heart, 
Which is the bell: so sighs and tears and groans
Show minutes, times, and but my time 
Runs posting on in Bolingbroke's joy, 
While I stand fooling here, his Jack o' the clock.
This music mads me; let it sound no more; 
For though have madmen to their wits, 
In me it seems it will wise men mad. 
Yet blessing on his heart that gives it me!
For 'tis a sign of love; and Richard 
Is a strange brooch in this all-hating world.

KING RICHARD II:
Thanks, noble peer; 
cheapest of us is ten groats too dear.

Where man never comes that sad dog

Towards him I made, but he was ware of me
And stole into the covert of the wood:
I, measuring his affections by my own,
That most are busied when they're most alone,
Pursued my humour not pursuing his,
And gladly shunn'd fled from me.

She is the fairies' midwife, comes 
In shape no bigger than an agate-stone
On the fore-finger of an alderman,
Drawn a team of atomies 
Athwart men's noses as they lie asleep;
Her wagon-spokes made of long spiders' legs, 
The cover of the wings of grasshoppers,
The traces of the smallest spider's web,
The collars of the moonshine's watery beams, 
Her whip of cricket's bone, the lash of film,
Her wagoner a small grey-coated gnat,
Not so big as a round little worm
Prick'd from the lazy finger of a maid;
Her chariot is an empty hazel-nut
Made the joiner squirrel or old grub, 
Time out o' mind the fairies' coachmakers.
And in this she gallops night by night 
Through lovers' and then they of love; 
O'er courtiers' knees, that dream on court'sies straight,
O'er lawyers' fingers, who straight on fees, 
O'er ladies ' lips, who straight on kisses dream,
Which oft the angry Mab with blisters plagues,
Because their sweetmeats tainted are: 
Sometime she gallops o'er a courtier's nose,
And then dreams he of smelling out a suit;
And sometime she with tithe-pig's tail 
Tickling a parson's nose as a' lies asleep,
Then dreams, he of another benefice:
Sometime she driveth o'er a soldier's neck, 
And then dreams he cutting foreign throats, 
Of breaches, Spanish blades, 
Of healths five-fathom deep; and then anon 
Drums in his ear, at which he starts and wakes,
And being thus frighted swears a prayer or two
sleeps again. This is that very

is as thin substance as the air

his face to the dew-dropping south.

FRIAR LAURENCE:
The smiles on the night, 
Chequering the eastern clouds with streaks of 
And flecked darkness like a drunkard reels
From forth day's path and Titan's fiery 
Now, ere the sun advance his burning eye,
The day to cheer and night's dank dew to dry,
I must up-fill this osier of ours 
With baleful weeds and precious-juiced flowers.
The earth that's nature's mother is her tomb;
What is burying grave that is womb, 
And from her womb children of divers kind
We sucking on natural bosom find, 
Many for many virtues excellent,
None but for and yet all different. 
O, mickle is the powerful grace that lies
In herbs, plants, stones, and their qualities: 
For nought so vile that on the earth doth live
But to the earth some special good doth give,
Nor so good but from that fair use 
Revolts from true birth, stumbling on abuse:
Virtue itself turns vice, being misapplied;
And vice sometimes by action dignified.
Within the infant rind of this small flower
Poison hath residence and medicine power:
this, being with part cheers each part; 
Being tasted, slays all senses with the heart. 
Two such opposed kings them 
as well as grace and will; 
And where the worser is predominant,
Full soon the canker death eats up that plant.

From off the battlements of yonder tower;
walk in thievish ways; or bid me lurk 
Where serpents are; chain me with roaring bears;
Or shut me nightly in a charnel-house,
quite with dead men's bones, 
reeky shanks and yellow chapless skulls; 
Or bid me go into a new-made grave
And hide with a dead shroud; 
Things to hear them told, have made me tremble; 
And will do it without fear or doubt, 
To live an unstain'd wife to my sweet love.

FRIAR LAURENCE:
then; go home, merry, give consent 
To marry Paris: Wednesday is to-morrow:
To-morrow night look that thou lie alone; 
Let not thy nurse lie with thee in thy chamber:
Take vial, being then in bed, 
And this distilled liquor drink thou off;
When presently through all thy veins shall run
A cold and drowsy humour, for no pulse
Shall keep his native progress, but surcease:
warmth, no breath, testify thou livest; 
The roses in thy lips and cheeks shall fade 
paly ashes, thy eyes' windows fall, 
Like death, when he shuts up the day of life;
Each part, deprived of supple government,
Shall, stiff and stark and cold, appear like death: 
And in this borrow'd likeness of shrunk death
Thou shalt continue two and forty hours,
And then awake a sleep. 
Now, when the bridegroom in the morning comes
To rouse thee from thy bed, there art thou dead: 
Then, as the manner of our country is,
In thy best robes uncover'd on the bier
Thou shalt be borne to that same ancient vault 
Where all the kindred of the Capulets lie.
In the mean time, against thou shalt awake,
Romeo by my letters our drift, 
And hither shall he come: and he and I
Will thy waking, that very night 
Shall Romeo bear thee hence to Mantua.
And this shall free thee from this present shame; 
If no inconstant toy, nor womanish fear,
Abate thy valour in the acting it.

for lives 
In these confusions. Heaven and yourself

And the better it for the maid: 
part her you could keep from death, 
But keeps part in eternal life. 
The most you sought was her promotion; 
For 'twas your heaven she should be advanced: 
And weep now, she is advanced 
Above the clouds, as high as heaven itself? 
O, in this love, you love your child so ill,
That you run mad, seeing that she is well: 
She's not married that married long; 
But she's best married that dies married young.
Dry up tears, and stick your rosemary 
On this fair corse; and, as the is, 
In all her best array bear her to church:
For though fond nature bids us an lament,
Yet nature's tears are reason's merriment.
 

All that we ordained festival, 
Turn from their office to black funeral;
Our instruments to bells, 
Our wedding cheer to a burial feast, 
Our solemn hymns to sullen dirges change,
Our flowers serve for a corse, 
And all things change them to the contrary.

hark! the fatal followers do pursue; 
And I am faint and cannot fly their fury:
And were I strong, I would not shun their fury:
The sands are number'd that make up my life;
Here must I stay, and here my life must end.
Come, bloody Clifford, rough Northumberland, 
I dare your quenchless fury to more rage:
I am your butt, and I abide your shot.

Or as a bear, encompass'd round with dogs,
Who having pinch'd a few and made them cry,
The rest stand all aloof, and bark at him.
So fared our father with his enemies;
So fled enemies my warlike father: 
Methinks, 'tis prize enough to be his son.
See the morning opes her golden 
And takes her farewell of the glorious sun! 
How well resembles it the prime of youth,
a prancing to his love!

KING HENRY 
This fares like to the morning's 
dying clouds contend with growing light, 
What time the shepherd, blowing of his nails, 
Can neither call it perfect day nor night. 
Now sways it this way, a mighty 
Forced by the tide to combat with the wind;
Now sways it that way, like the selfsame sea
Forced to retire by fury of the wind:
Sometime the flood prevails, and then the wind;
Now one the better, then another best;
Both tugging to be victors, breast to breast,
Yet neither conqueror nor conquered: 
So is the equal of this fell war.
Here on this molehill will I sit me down.
To whom God will, be the victory! 
For Margaret my queen, and Clifford too, 
Have me the battle; swearing both 
They prosper best of when I am 
Would I were dead! if God's good will were so;
For is world grief and woe? 
O God! methinks it were a happy life,

To sit upon hill, as do now, 
To carve out dials quaintly, point by point,
Thereby to see the minutes how they run,
make the hour full complete; 
How many hours bring about the day;
many days will up the year; 
How many years a mortal man may live.
When this is known, then to divide the times:
So many hours must I tend my flock;
So many hours I take my rest; 
So many hours must I contemplate;
So hours must sport myself; 
So many days my ewes have been with young;
weeks ere the poor fools will ean: 
So many years ere I shall shear the fleece:
So minutes, days, months, and years, 
Pass'd over to the end they were created,
Would bring white hairs unto a quiet grave.
Ah, what a life were this! how sweet! how lovely!
Gives the hawthorn-bush a sweeter 
To shepherds looking on their silly sheep,
Than doth a rich embroider'd canopy
To kings fear 
O, yes, it doth; a thousand-fold it 
And to conclude, the shepherd's homely curds,
His cold thin drink out of his leather bottle.
His wonted sleep under a fresh tree's shade,
All secure sweetly he enjoys, 
Is far beyond a prince's delicates,
His viands sparkling in a golden cup,
His body couched in a 
mistrust, and treason on him. 

Son: 
Ill the wind that profits nobody. 
This man, whom hand to hand I slew in fight,
May be possessed with some store of crowns;
And I, that haply take them from him now,
May yet ere night yield both life and 
To man else, as this dead man doth me. 
Who's this? O God! it is my father's face,
Whom in this conflict I unwares have kill'd. 
O heavy times, such events! 
From London by the king was I press'd forth;
My father, being the Earl of Warwick's man,
Came on the part of York, by master; 
And I, who his hands received life, him 
Have by my hands of life bereaved him. 
Pardon me, God, I knew not what I did!
And pardon, father, for I knew not thee!
My tears shall wipe away these bloody marks; 
And no more words till they have flow'd their fill.
 
KING VI: 
O piteous O bloody times! 
Whiles lions war and battle for their dens,
Poor harmless lambs abide their enmity.
Weep, wretched man, I'll aid thee tear for tear;
And let our hearts and eyes, civil 
Be blind with tears, and break o'ercharged with grief.

me thy gold, if thou hast any

one purple blood well resembles;

Having the fearful flying hare in sight, 
With fiery eyes sparkling for very wrath, 
And bloody steel grasp'd in their ireful hands, 
Are at our backs; and therefore hence amain.

EXETER:

Or else come after: I'll away before.

KING HENRY VI: 
Nay, take me with thee, good sweet Exeter:
I fear to stay, but love to go 
Whither the queen intends. Forward;

I can add colours to the chameleon,

And set the murderous Machiavel to school.
Can do this, and cannot a crown?

with a pedigree?

Even in the downfall of his mellow'd years,
When brought him to the door of death? 
No, Warwick, no; while life upholds this arm,
This arm upholds Lancaster. 
 
WARWICK: 
And I the house of York.

Queen Margaret, Prince Edward, and Oxford,

QUEEN MARGARET:
Heavens grant that Warwick's words bewitch not! 

LEWIS XI:

Is Edward your true king? for I were loath
To link with him that were not lawful chosen.
 
WARWICK:
Thereon I pawn my credit and mine honour.

KING LEWIS XI:
But is he gracious in the people's eye?

WARWICK:
The more that Henry was unfortunate.

Unto our sister Bona. 

WARWICK:
Such it seems

Whereof the root was fix'd in virtue's ground, 
The leaves and fruit maintain'd with beauty's sun,
Exempt from envy, but not from disdain, 
the Lady Bona his pain.

For I intend but only to surprise him.
You that will follow me to this attempt,
Applaud the name Henry with your leader. 
Why, then, let's on our way in silent sort:
For Warwick and his friends, God and Saint George!

3 KING HENRY VI


Great lords, wise men ne'er sit and wail their loss,
But cheerly seek how to redress their harms.
What though the mast be now blown overboard,
The cable broke, holding-anchor lost, 
half our sailors swallow'd 
Yet lives our pilot still. Is't meet that he 
Should leave the helm and like a fearful lad
With tearful eyes add water to the sea
And give more strength to that which hath too much,
Whiles, moan, the ship splits on the 
Which industry and courage might have saved?
Ah, what a shame! ah, what a fault were this!
Say Warwick was anchor; what of that? 
And Montague topmost; of him? 
Our slaughter'd friends the tackles; what of these?
Why, is not Oxford here another anchor? 
And Somerset another goodly mast?
The friends of France our shrouds and tacklings?
And, though unskilful, why not Ned and I
For once allow'd the skilful pilot's charge?
We will not from the helm to sit and weep,
But keep our course, though the rough wind say no,
shelves rocks that threaten with wreck. 
As good to chide the waves as speak them 
And what is Edward but ruthless sea?
What Clarence but of deceit? 
And Richard but a ragged fatal rock? 
All these the enemies to our poor bark.
Say you can swim; alas, 'tis but a while!
Tread on the sand; why, there you quickly sink:
Bestride the the tide will wash you off, 
Or else you that's threefold death. 
This speak lords, to let you understand, 
If some of would from us, 
That there's no hoped-for mercy with the brothers
More than with ruthless waves, with sands and rocks.
Why, courage then! what cannot be avoided
'Twere childish to lament or fear.

3 KING HENRY VI

KING EDWARD IV:
Once more we sit in England's royal 
Re-purchased with the blood of enemies.
What valiant foemen, like to autumn's corn,
Have we mow'd down, in tops of all their pride!
Three Dukes of Somerset, threefold renown'd
For hardy and undoubted champions;
Two Cliffords, as the father and the son,
And two braver men 
Ne'er spurr'd their coursers at the trumpet's sound;
them, the two bears, Warwick Montague, 
That in their chains fetter'd the kingly lion
And made the forest tremble when they roar'd.
Thus have we swept suspicion from our seat
And made our footstool of security.
Come hither, Bess, and my 
Young Ned, for thee, thine uncles and myself
Have in our armours watch'd the winter's night,
Went all afoot in summer's scalding heat,
That thou mightst repossess the crown in peace;
And of our labours thou shalt reap the gain.

Boldly 'not guilty;' the imposition clear'd
Hereditary ours.

O, cut my lace, lest my heart, cracking it,
Break too. 

First Lord:
What fit this, good 

PAULINA: 
What studied torments, tyrant, hast for me?
What wheels? racks? fires? what flaying? boiling? 
In leads or oils? what old or newer torture
Must I receive, whose every word deserves 
To taste of thy most worst? Thy tyranny 
Together working with thy jealousies,
Fancies too weak for boys, too green and idle
For girls of nine, O, think what they have done
And then run mad indeed, for all 
Thy by-gone fooleries were but spices of it. 
That thou betray'dst Polixenes,'twas nothing;
That did but show thee, of fool, inconstant 
And damnable ingrateful: nor was't much,
wouldst poison'd good Camillo's honour, 
To have him kill a king: poor trespasses,
More monstrous standing by: whereof I reckon
The casting forth to crows thy baby-daughter
To be none little; though 
Would water of fire done't: 
Nor is't directly laid to thee, the death
Of the young prince, whose honourable thoughts,
high one so tender, cleft the 
That could conceive a gross foolish sire 
Blemish'd his gracious dam: this is not, no,
to thy but the last,--O 
I have said, cry 'woe!' the queen, the queen, 
The sweet'st, dear'st creature's dead,
and vengeance for't
Not dropp'd down yet.
 
First Lord: 
The higher powers forbid!

PAULINA:
I say she's dead; I'll swear't. If word nor oath
Prevail not, go and see: if you can bring 
Tincture or lustre in her lip, her eye,
Heat outwardly or breath within, serve you 
As I would do the gods. But, O thou tyrant!
Do not repent these things, for they are heavier
Than all thy woes can stir; therefore betake thee
To nothing but despair. A thousand knees
Ten thousand years together, naked, fasting,
Upon a barren mountain and still winter 
In storm perpetual, could not move gods 
To look that way thou wert. 

LEONTES:
Go go on 
Thou canst not speak too much; I have deserved 
All tongues to talk bitterest. 

First Lord: 
Say no more:
Howe'er the business goes, you have made fault 
I' the boldness of your speech.

PAULINA:
I am sorry for't:
All faults I make, when I shall come to know them,
I do repent. Alas! I have show'd too much
rashness of a woman: he is touch'd 
To the noble heart. What's gone what's past help 
Should be do not receive affliction 
At my petition; I beseech you, rather
Let me be punish'd, that have minded you
you forget. Now, good my liege 
Sir, royal sir, forgive a woman: 
The love I bore your queen--lo, fool again!--
speak of her no more, nor of your children; 
I'll not remember you of my own 
Who lost too: take your patience to 
And I'll say nothing.

LEONTES: 
Thou speak but well 
When the truth; I better

One grave shall be for both: upon them shall
The causes of their death unto 
Our shame Once a day I'll visit 
The chapel where tears shed there 
be my recreation: so long as 
Will bear up with this exercise, so long
I vow use it. Come and 
Unto these sorrows.

I by this. I do believe 
Hermione hath suffer'd death, and that
Apollo would, this being indeed the issue

Either for life or death, upon the earth
Of its right father. Blossom, speed thee well!
There lie, there thy character: there these; 
Which may, if fortune please, both breed thee, pretty,
rest thine. The storm begins; poor wretch, 
That for thy mother's fault art thus exposed
To loss and what may follow! Weep I cannot,
But my heart bleeds; and most accursed am I
To be by oath enjoin'd to this. Farewell!
The day frowns more and more: thou'rt like to have 
A lullaby too rough: I never saw
The heavens so dim by A clamour!

Time:
I, that please try both joy and terror 
Of good and bad, that makes and unfolds error,
Now take upon me, in the name of Time,
To use my wings. Impute a crime 
To me my swift passage, that I 
O'er sixteen years and leave the growth untried
Of that wide gap, since is in my power 
To o'erthrow law and in one hour 
To and o'erwhelm custom. Let me 
The same I am, ere ancient'st order was
Or what is now received: I witness to
The times that so shall I 
To the freshest things now reigning and make stale
The of this present, as tale 
Now seems to it. Your patience this allowing, 
I turn my glass and give my scene such growing
As had between: Leontes leaving, 
The effects of his fond jealousies so grieving
That he shuts up himself, imagine me,
Gentle spectators, that I now may be
fair Bohemia, and remember well, 
I mentioned a son o' king's, which Florizel 
I now name to you; and with speed so pace
To speak of Perdita, now grown in grace
Equal with wondering: what of her ensues 
I list not but let Time's news 
Be known when 'tis brought forth.
A shepherd's daughter,
And what to her adheres, which follows after,
Is the argument of Time. Of this allow,
If ever you have spent time ere now;

POLIXENES:
I pray thee, good Camillo, be no more importunate:
'tis a sickness denying thee any thing; a death to
grant this. 
 
CAMILLO:
It is fifteen years since I saw my country: though
I have for the most part been aired abroad, I
desire to lay my bones there. Besides, the penitent
king, my master, hath sent for me; to whose feeling
sorrows I might be some allay, or I o'erween to
think so, which is another spur to my departure.

POLIXENES:

thee thine own made; not to

are even now to be 
Say to me, when sawest thou the Prince Florizel, my

they have approved their virtues.

CAMILLO:

not before mine honour, nor my lusts 
Burn hotter than my faith.

Nothing but that; move still, still so,
And own no other function: each your doing,
So singular in each particular,
Crowns what you are doing in the present deed,
That all your acts are queens.

So to enforce or qualify the laws 
As to your soul seems good. Give me your hand:
I'll privily love the people, 
But do not like to stage me to their eyes:
Through it do well, I do not relish well
Their loud applause and vehement; 
Nor do think the man 
That does affect it. Once more, fare you well.

Be absolute either or 
Shall thereby be the sweeter. Reason with life:

That none but fools would keep: a breath thou art,
Servile to all the skyey influences,
That habitation, where thou keep'st, 
Hourly afflict: merely, thou art death's fool;
For thou labour'st by thy flight to shun 
And yet runn'st toward him still. Thou art not noble;
For all the accommodations that thou bear'st
Are nursed by baseness. Thou'rt by no means valiant;
For thou dost fear the soft and tender fork
Of a poor worm. of rest is sleep, 
And that thou oft provokest; yet grossly fear'st
Thy is no more. art not thyself; 
For thou exist'st on many a thousand grains
That issue out of dust. Happy thou art not;
For what thou hast not, still thou strivest to get, 
And what thou hast, forget'st. Thou not certain; 
For thy complexion shifts to strange effects,
After the moon. If rich, thou'rt 
For, like an ass whose back with ingots bows,
Thou bear's heavy riches a journey, 
And death thee. Friend hast thou none; 
thine own bowels, which do thee sire, 
The mere effusion of thy proper loins,
Do the gout, serpigo, and the 
For ending thee no sooner. Thou hast nor youth nor age,
But, as it were, an after-dinner's sleep,
Dreaming on both; for blessed youth 
Becomes as aged, and doth beg the alms
Of palsied eld; and when thou art old and rich,
Thou hast neither heat, affection, limb, nor beauty, 
To make thy pleasant. What's yet in 
That bears the name of in this life 
Lie hid moe thousand deaths: yet death we fear,
That makes these odds all even.

And six or seven winters more respect
Than a perpetual honour. Darest thou die? 
The sense of death is most in apprehension;
the poor beetle, that we 
In corporal sufferance finds a pang as great 
As when a giant dies. 

CLAUDIO: 
Why give you me this shame?
Think I can a fetch 
If I must die, 
I will encounter darkness as a bride,
And hug it in mine arms.
 
ISABELLA:
There spake my brother; there my father's grave
Did utter forth voice. die: 
Thou art too noble to conserve a life
In base appliances. This outward-sainted deputy,
Whose settled visage and deliberate word
Nips youth i' the head and follies doth 
As falcon doth the fowl, is yet a devil
His filth within being cast, he would appear 
pond deep as hell. 
 

The prenzie Angelo!
 
ISABELLA: 
O, 'tis the cunning livery of hell,
The damned'st body to invest and cover
In guards! Dost thou Claudio? 
If I would yield him my virginity,
Thou mightst be freed.
 

heavens! it cannot be. 

ISABELLA:
he would give't thee, from this rank 
So to offend him still. This night's the time
That I should do what I abhor to name,
Or else thou diest to-morrow.

CLAUDIO:
Thou shalt do't. 

ISABELLA: 
O, were it but my life,
I'ld throw it down your deliverance 
As frankly as a pin.
 

Thanks, dear 

ISABELLA:

CLAUDIO:
Yes. Has he affections in him, 
That thus can make him bite the law by the nose, 
When would force it? Sure, is sin, 
Or of the deadly seven, it is the least. 

ISABELLA:
is the least? 

CLAUDIO: 
If it were damnable, he being so wise,
Why would he for the momentary trick
Be perdurably fined? O Isabel!

ISABELLA:
What says my brother? 
 
CLAUDIO:
Death is a fearful thing. 
 
ISABELLA:
And life a 

CLAUDIO: 
Ay, and we not where; 
To lie in cold obstruction and to rot;
This sensible warm motion to become
A kneaded clod; and the delighted spirit
To bathe in fiery floods, or to reside
In thrilling region of thick-ribbed ice;
To be imprison'd winds, 
And with violence round about 
The pendent world; or to be worse than worst
that lawless and incertain 
Imagine 'tis too horrible! 
The weariest and most loathed 
That age, ache, penury and imprisonment
Can on nature is a paradise 
To what we fear of death.

ISABELLA: 
Alas, 

CLAUDIO: 
Sweet sister, let me live:
What sin you do to save a brother's 
Nature dispenses the deed far 
That it becomes a virtue.

ISABELLA:
O you beast! 
O faithless coward! O dishonest wretch!
Wilt thou be made a man out of my vice? 
not a kind of incest, to take life 
From thine own sister's shame? What should I think?
Heaven shield my mother play'd my father fair!
For such a warped slip of wilderness
Ne'er issued from his blood. Take my defiance!
Die, perish! Might but my bending down
Reprieve thee from thy fate, should proceed: 
I'll pray a thousand prayers for thy death,
No word to save thee.


Nay, hear Isabel.

warrant for it: it hath not moved him at all.

ANGELO:

And five years since there was some speech of marriage
Betwixt myself and her; which was broke off,
Partly for that her promised proportions
Came short of composition, but in chief 
For that her reputation was disvalued
In levity: since which time of five years
I never spake with her, saw her, nor heard from her,
Upon my faith and honour.
 

Noble prince,
As there comes light from heaven and words from breath,
As there is sense in truth and truth virtue, 
I am affianced this man's wife as strongly
As words could make up vows: and, my good lord,
But Tuesday night last gone garden-house 
knew me a wife. As this true, 
Let me safety raise me from my knees 
Or else for ever be confixed here,
A marble monument!

Thy hounds shall make the welkin answer them 
And fetch shrill echoes from earth.
